Help Protect Our Schuylkill Community

Above grade is not below ground

Help Protect Our Schuylkill Community

The Problem

There is an inconvenient truth in the City's approval of One Riverside, and a group of concerned neighbors is asking for your support in appealing the project's Conditional Zoning Permit.

The huge size and layout of Dranoff Properties' proposed highrise tower is based on an incorrect interpretation of the meaning of the City's new Zoning Code.

We believe the One Riverside project is bigger than allowed by law, because the City is mistakenly allowing about 3 extra stories based on a “bonus” provision in the Zoning Code that awards developers with bigger buildings when projects include parking entirely “below grade.” But, clearly, this parking wouldn't be below grade: The garage would rise a full story above grade.

The Conditional Zoning Permit appeal currently underway challenges these anomalies. One Riverside is built on faulty interpretations of the Zoning Code that will set a dangerous precedent for future development along any river or waterway in Philadelphia.

The Solution: Make your opposition known!

Sign on below to keep underground parking where it belongs, below grade, and save our riverside open space! Your names will be sent to Councilman Johnson and Mayor Nutter:

The proposed 21-story tower and its garage would completely eliminate the open space lot just beyond the Community Garden (dog park in foreground), and dwarf adjacent townhouses.


This view would be blocked by the One Riverside parking garage.

Background

  • Dranoff Properties Inc. is proposing to build a 21-story, 147-unit highrise at the Locust Street entrance to Schuylkill Banks.
  • Currently, the property is a 76-space open-air neighborhood parking lot. The project replaces the lot with the tower and parking garage, with 81 spots for the exclusive use of project residents.
  • The bonus provision of the new Zoning Code awards additional building space for constructing parking that is entirely “below grade,” so that it is not visible from the sidewalk.
  • The City awarded this project a 27,000 square foot bonus on the ridiculous theory that “underground” means below the level of a 100-year flood, which at this location is about 7 feet above ground level. This bonus would translate into three extra stories and an additional 27 dwelling units.
  • For more details on the legal issue, please read this legal analysis (PDF).

Who we are: This website has been prepared by neighbors concerned about the size and density of the proposed One Riverside tower, and its inappropriateness for our cherished riverside open space.
